serviceName: Make a lasting power of attorney
startContent:
You can make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) using our online service.

If you want to, you can ask someone else to use the service for you, for example a family member, friend or solicitor. You will still need to make all the decisions about what goes on the LPA.

We’ll save the LPA as you progress so you do not need to complete it in one go. You can sign out at any time and come back later.

It costs £82 to apply to register an LPA.

Information you'll need

You may find it useful to gather some information before you start.

As well as your details, you’ll need the names, addresses and dates of birth of:

  • the attorneys
  • the replacement attorneys, if you decide to have any

You’ll also need the name and address of your certificate provider.

Documents, equipment and other things you'll need

You'll also need:

  • a debit or credit card to pay the application fee
  • a mobile phone, so we can text you a security code
  • documents or information to prove your identity
What you need to prove your identity

When you make an LPA, we need to check your identity. We do this to protect you and prevent fraud.

You can prove your identity by:

  • entering details from your passport or driving licence
  • entering details from, and uploading a photo of, a recent payslip or P60
  • signing in to your Government Gateway, Department for Work and Pensions, or online banking account, and letting us confirm your details with those organisations
  • taking documents to a Post Office
  • asking a professional (like a teacher, civil servant or solicitor) to confirm your identity

whichTypeOfLpaToMake: Which type of LPA do you want to make?
whichTypeOfLpaToMakeContent:
There are 2 types of LPA. You can make an LPA that covers decisions about your:

  • money, finances and any property you own
  • health care, medical treatment and personal welfare

You can have one or both types of LPA.

They do not have to be made at the same time and you can reuse any information you enter to make other LPAs later.

You can choose different people to be your attorneys for each LPA.

Find out more about the 2 types of LPAs

whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheAttorneysDetailsCo:
Your attorneys are the people who'll be able to help you make decisions about your finances, if you ever want or need their help in the future.

It's important that you choose people you trust to respect your wishes and act in your best interests.

You can have more than 1 attorney. Most people have between 1 and 3.

An attorney must:

  • be aged 18 or over
  • have mental capacity (be able to make decisions)

Someone cannot be an attorney if they are:

  • bankrupt or have a debt relief order
  • on the Disclosure and Barring Service barred list (someone is normally put on this list if they have a criminal conviction or caution that means they’re not allowed to work with vulnerable people)

You'll be asked if you would like to add replacement attorneys in a separate question. They step in if your original attorneys are unable or unwilling to continue.

Find out more about attorneys

restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerTitle: Restrict the decisions your attorneys can make
restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerContent:
This optional section lets you add extra information for your attorneys, {{.AllAttorneysFirstNames}}, to guide the decisions they can make on your behalf. We call this adding 'restrictions and conditions' to your LPA.

What you say here will tell {{.AllAttorneysFirstNames}} things they:

  • must not do ('restrictions')
  • can only do in certain circumstances ('conditions')

You do not have to add restrictions or conditions to your LPA. You may prefer to talk to {{.AllAttorneysFirstNames}} about your wishes, rather than writing them into your LPA.

There are legal rules about what you can and cannot tell your attorneys to do, so it's important to read our guidance on writing restrictions and conditions.
restrictionExamplesContent:
Example restrictions: things the attorneys must not do

  • 'My attorneys must not sell my home.'

Example restrictions: things your attorneys can only do in certain circumstances

  • 'My attorneys must not sell my home unless, in my doctor's opinion, I can no longer live independently.'
restrictionsHint: It's important that you word any restrictions and conditions clearly and carefully.
restrictionsTooLong: Restrictions must be 10,000 or fewer characters
whoDoYouWantToBeCertificateProviderTitle: Who do you want to be your certificate provider?
whoDoYouWantToBeCertificateProviderGuida:
A certificate provider is an independent person who talks to you to check you understand your LPA and want to make it.

Most people choose a friend, neighbour or colleague to be their certificate provider.
whatYourCertificateProviderHasToDo:
What your certificate provider has to do

Your certificate provider has to:

  • read your LPA once you've finished making it
  • meet you in person to talk about your LPA in private
  • witness you signing your LPA

We’ll then ask your certificate provider to:

  • confirm their identity
  • confirm they’ve discussed your LPA with you
  • tell us if they have any concerns about your LPA - for example, if they think someone is pressuring you to make it

We call this 'providing a certificate'. They can do this using our online service or a paper form.

If we ever have any concerns about your LPA, we may ask your certificate provider to tell us more about the conversation they had with you.
whoToChooseAsYourCertificateProvider:
Who to choose as your certificate provider

You can choose either:

  • someone you’ve known well for at least 2 years, for example, a friend or neighbour (but not a relative)
  • a doctor, lawyer or another professional with the skills to check whether you understand your LPA

Choose someone:

  • you’re comfortable having an open, honest conversation with
  • who will speak up if they think something is wrong

They’ll need to have their own mobile phone.
whoCannotBeACertificateProvider:
Who cannot be a certificate provider

Your certificate provider cannot be:

  • under 18 years old
  • an attorney on your LPA
  • related to you or {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }} (this includes step-relations, in-laws, husbands, wives, partners, boyfriends and girlfriends)
  • a business partner or employee of you or {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }}
  • someone who works for a care home where you live, or their relative
detailsYoullNeedAboutYourCertificateProv:
Details you'll need about your certificate provider

You'll need their:

  • full name
  • date of birth
  • mobile phone number
  • email or postal address

Find out more about certificate providers, and who can and cannot take on the role.
certificateProviderDetailsHint: Remember, your certificate provider must be 18 or over. They cannot be a member of your family (this includes step-relations and in-laws) or of the attorneys' families.

whatHappensIfIChangeDetails:
If you want to change your LPA after you’ve had the conversation with your certificate provider, you can.

After you've made the changes, you’ll need to have the conversation with your certificate provider again, so you can talk about the updated LPA.

whatHappensIfIWantToMakeChanges: What happens if I want to make changes after I've signed?
whatHappensIfIWantToMakeChangesContent:
It is possible to change your LPA after you’ve signed it and had the conversation with your certificate provider. However, you will need to:

  • sign the LPA again
  • have another conversation with your certificate provider, so you can talk about the updated LPA.

Once the LPA has been registered, you can remove an attorney, but cannot make any other changes.

If you want to make other changes, you can cancel the LPA and make a new one.

nextStepsList:
1. We'll contact {{ .CpFirstNames }} and ask them to confirm their identity. They also need to sign your LPA to confirm they've discussed it with you. We call this 'providing a certificate'.
  2. We'll then contact {{ .AttorneysFullNames }} and ask them to sign your LPA as your attorneys.

howShouldAttorneysMakeDecisions: How should your attorneys make decisions?
jointlyAndSeverallyHint:
Your attorneys can make decisions together or on their own.

This means your attorneys can share tasks and responsibilities. It also means that if one of your attorneys is unable to act, decisions can still be made without them. Most people choose this option as it’s the most practical.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys acting 'jointly and severally'.
jointlyHintAttorneys:
All your attorneys must agree on every decision, however big or small.

This means if one of your attorneys can no longer act, none of your other attorneys will be able to act either, unless you state otherwise in your restrictions. It also means that if your attorneys cannot agree on a decision, it cannot be made without going to court.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working 'jointly'.
jointlyAndSeverallyMixedHumanised: Some decisions must be made together
jointlyAndSeverallyMixedHint:
All your attorneys must agree on some decisions but can make other decisions on their own. You must state which decisions need to be agreed together.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working 'jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for other decisions'.
decisionDetailsHint: Please tell us which decisions your attorneys must make together. Take a look at the guidance for examples if your attorneys will be making decisions together.
howAttorneysShouldMakeDecisions: how the attorneys should make decisions
howReplacementAttorneysShouldMakeDecisio: how the replacement attorneys should make decisions
jointlyReplacementWarning: Replacement attorneys are an important backup when attorneys are appointed to act jointly.
jointlyReplacementWarningContent:
If you do not appoint any replacement attorneys and one of the original attorneys dies or can no longer act, the LPA will stop working.

If you appoint replacement attorneys and one of the original attorneys dies or can no longer act:

  • ALL the original attorneys will be replaced by the replacement attorneys, unless you state otherwise in your instructions
  • the original attorneys will not be able to make any decisions on your behalf anymore
mixedReplacementWarning: You appointed your attorneys to act jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for others.
mixedReplacementWarningContent:
This means that if an original attorney dies or can no longer act:

  • all the replacement attorneys step in and take over making the joint decisions
  • the remaining original attorneys will not be able to make the joint decisions anymore, unless you state otherwise in your instructions
  • the replacement and remaining original attorneys can make all other decisions together or individually

Most donors choose for all the replacement attorneys to step in together as soon as 1 of the original attorneys can no longer act. However, if you would prefer the replacement attorneys to step in later or in a specific order, select 1 of the other 2 options.

howToConfirmYourIdentityAndSignSteps:
1. Confirm your identity

This is so we can be sure it's you that's about to sign the LPA. It should take less than 5 minutes.

2. Discuss your LPA with {{.CertificateProviderFirstNames}}

You should meet in private. {{.AttorneysFullNames}} should not be there.

3. Sign your LPA

Sign your LPA online. We will then send {{.CertificateProviderFullName}} a unique code by text message, that you must enter to prove they were with you.
whatYoullNeedToConfirmYourIdentity: What you'll need to confirm your identity
whatYoullNeedToConfirmYourIdentityConten:
To confirm your identity, you'll need 3 things from this list.

  • Your passport
    This must be your current passport or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name on your passport must be the same as on your LPA.
  • Your driving licence
    This must be your current licence or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name and address on your licence must be the same as on your LPA.
  • A GOV.UK Account
    We’ll ask you to sign in to your account so we can confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you.
  • Post Office EasyID
    Post Office EasyID is a secure digital app that lets you confirm your identity online. We’ll confirm your name, address and date of birth through Post Office EasyID. We will not see any other information Post Office EasyID holds about you.
  • A Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) account and your National Insurance Number
    We’ll check your details with DWP - they'll confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you.
  • A utility bill
